results.title: Spirit, dance and connection = Spirit, dance & connection
results.creator_credit: Haryne Uta, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Dancing is a way of life, culture and part of our identity. Haryne Uta, a young Torres Strait Islander, started dancing from a very young age. He tells of his journey to not taking it very seriously to realising, under the guidance of his elders, how crucial dancing is to Haryne’s spiritual awakening. The stories of the dance awoke in Haryne a sense of pride and connection to the spiritual world, people and the land.

group.title: This is me : foundation for young Australians (July 2009) : Digital Storytelling project

results.title: My "perfect" family
results.creator_credit: Ebonie Sadler-Small, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: While Ebonie Sadler-Small grew up with her grandmother, she attributes her entire family to the inspiring youth leader she is today. Ebonie feels that in not having a conventional family, she has gained an non-judgemental, adventurous and optimistic outlook on life. With her family and friends, Ebonie has been encouraged and supported and she feels this has given her the strength and confidence to achieve in life.

results.title: Our trip to Sydney
results.creator_credit: Bryce O'Neill-Baker, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Bryce O’Neill-Baker tells of the time when he was asked if he wanted to go to Sydney for a short trip. The next day, he joined a bus with family members and others from his community to visit Sydney for the weekend. As well as the normal sightseeing, he also got to experience the NAIDOC festival and warmly shares the effect this time had on his family.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bryce O’Neill-Baker, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: A Turning point
results.creator_credit: Noel Williamson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Noel Williamson joined the RAAF because he wanted adventure and he wanted to serve. While his limited education kept him grounded, he speaks fondly of his time in the RAAF, and the opportunities that he grasped with both hands once the war ended.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Noel Williamson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: The Lost soldier
results.creator_credit: Ken Saunders, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Ken Saunders reflects on the silence reverie of his father, a returned soldier. He never spoke about the war and, when Ken tried to broach the subject, told Ken to let sleeping dogs lie. This left Ken wondering about the demons that his dad confronts alone and the war that took his brother Harry. Spurred by the belief that all warriors need to come home, Ken initiates his own research to find out all he can about Harry and, eventually, return his brother’s spirit home.

results.title: The Youngest WAAAF in the service
results.creator_credit: Jean Williamson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: For Jean Williamson, her time at the Women’s Auxiliary Australian Airforce was new and exciting and, much to her disappointment, short. She joined a few months shy of the end of the war. Still, as she looks back through an album of memories, she reflects fondly on friends made, good times and meeting her husband Noel. She also considers how at that time she wasn’t aware she was an Indigenous Australian. When she found out, she responded by becoming heavily involved in the Indigenous community. Despite her pale complexion, Jean Williamson proudly declares her black heart.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jean Williamson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: The Sleeping dragon
results.creator_credit: Graham Atkinson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: The attack on the World Trade Centre in September 2001 resonated with veterans like Graham Atkinson, reminding him of his time in Vietnam during the 1960s and 1970s. Graham tells of how being in the army taught him strength, respect and a sense of dignity for all. Vietnam was a turning point for this Indigenous Australian. He returned highly politicised and railed against violence in his community but left with decades of unresolved memories.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Graham Atkinson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Bringing his spirit home
results.creator_credit: Dot Peters, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Dot Peters’ father was 39 when he joined World War II. He fought in the Middle East and was later captured in Java and sent to a Prisoner of War camp in Japan. He died there, leaving a grieving family wondering what he went through. Simultaneously, they witnessed the injustices inflicted on fellow Indigenous servicemen who had experienced equality overseas, only to find it stripped away on their return. This inspired Dot to dedicate the rest of her life to fighting for Indigenous rights, eventually collaborating with the Shrine of Remembrance to recognise the contribution made by Indigenous people during the war. This fight has helped her to bring her father’s spirit home, to bestow upon his memory a sense of belonging, recognition and honour.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Dot Peters, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Wooden chains
results.creator_credit: Jim Willox, ACMI and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: He would whittle away at scraps of wood for hours, lost in the quiet moments of himself, perhaps trying to make sense of the war, we’ll never know. A son’s reflection on the life of his father, a veteran from World War I, who returned both psychologically and physically scarred but would never share these scars with the rest of his family, choosing to spend his later years in quiet and solitary contemplation. Jim Willox and his family can only guess at the trauma that bellies the whittling his dad so regularly engaged in. A tribute to a war veteran by his son, who will never fully comprehend all he went through.

results.title: Wings
results.creator_credit: Jack McMahon, ACMI and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Jack McMahon wanted to be a pilot for as long as he can remember. When war was declared, he signed up as soon as he could and, unsurprisingly, joined the Air Force. He warmly talks about his time during World War II, the friendships and bonds created and the crucial moments during the war where he needed to step up and take a chance. Despite being told by his instructor that he was going to kill himself, Jack McMahon returned to Australia and was honoured for his services during the Anzac Day football match in 2008.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jack McMahon, ACMI and ACMI Digital Storytelling
